Determine the range of values z can take, considering the condition z > max(x, y).
Consider the possible range for x and y given a specific value of z.
Calculate how many pairs (x, y) can be chosen for each valid value of z.
Sum the number of valid triples (x, y, z) across all potential values of z within its range.
Express the total count in terms of n.

For each value z, determine possible values for x and y such that both are less than z.
Calculate the number of combinations for x and y for each fixed value of z.
Sum the number of valid (x, y, z) triples across all considered values of z to find the total count of valid triples.

Calculate the number of valid choices for z once x and y are chosen.
